isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - Hydraulic Anti-Lock Braking System (HABS) Installation Guide for OEMs and Body Builders (Includes Body Builder Installation Information) - Hydraulic ABS Bleeding Procedure for Unfilled (Dry) Modulator Assembly - Manual Bleed Procedure with Electronic Control Equipment

svcproc.title: Manual Bleed Procedure with Electronic Control Equipment

note.para: The electronic control equipment must be capable of actuating (energizing) the outlet solenoid valves for each wheel for approximately 10 seconds and activating the pump of the modulator. The inlet solenoid valve should be open (de-energized). The Meritor WABCO Diagnostic Controller can be used to do this.

step1.para: Apply the parking brake and chock the tires. Turn the ignition OFF.

note.para: The ignition must remain off for the initial bleed procedure; energizing the unit during bleeding must be impossible.

step1.para: Perform brake bleed procedure for wet module, bleeding the circuit and master cylinder if required prior to connecting electronic control equipment. Use Pressure Bleed Method if equipment is available; if not, use the Manual Bleed Method.
Install electronic control equipment to ECU, or to the modulator assembly and pump.
Turn ignition switch ON or power electronic control equipment.
Push on brake pedal with maximum force (firm pedal) and hold.
Activate the pulse function on the electronic control equipment starting with the longest brake circuit, typically the rear.
Release brake pedal for 5 seconds and activate the pump of the modulator for approximately 5 seconds.
Repeat Steps 5 through 7 three additional times.
Perform manual bleed on appropriate wheels.

note.para: To perform a manual bleed, follow Steps 2 through 8 under "Manual Bleed Procedure (Wet Modulator Assembly)."

step1.para: Repeat Steps 5 through 9 for the remaining 2 brake actuators.

note.para: If a firm brake pedal resistance is felt and the brake pedal pushes back when the solenoids and pump are simultaneously actuated for each brake circuit, the system bleed procedure is complete. If there is no firm pedal resistance, repeat the bleed procedure and/or look into brake system defect, (leaks, etc.).
